propositions.text: William Patkery went for his usual walk at seven in the morning.
He was walking on the short grass on the cliff top.
Two hundred feet below him lay the English Channel.
The air was fresh, and there were no birds.
There was no sound except the occasional cry of a gull from the distant beach.
There was no one to be seen but Patkery.
The dew on the grass sparkled as if it were a new world from the Creator's hand.
But Patkery did not think that.
To him the dew on the grass merely represented the fact that the ground moisture had not yet been dried up by the sun.
This fact flashed through his subconscious, and his consciousness was engaged in a decision.
He was hungry and had to decide whether to turn back to the coast guard station in the gorge or to walk on to Westover for a morning paper to know about a murder two hours earlier.
One might say that with a radio, the advantage of an early newspaper is gone.
But it is always a goal.
Whether in wartime or peace, a person must have a goal in life.
You can't walk all the way to Westover just to look at the coast.
Returning with a newspaper for breakfast would make one feel a little better.
Yes, perhaps he should go to town.
His footsteps in black square-toed boots quickened slightly, the shiny uppers flashing in the sun.
They were very well-maintained boots.

One might think that since Patkery had to obey orders and keep his boots shining in the prime of his life, he should now let them get dusty to show his uniqueness, express his personality, or simply to break free from boring discipline.
But no, Patkery still polished his boots because he liked it.
Perhaps he had a certain masochistic tendency, but luckily he hadn't read much about it, so he wasn't bothered.
As for expressing personality, if you told him certain symptoms, he would of course understand, but he wouldn't know the technical terms.
During his service, they called it 'going against the grain'.
A gull suddenly swooped past the cliff top, screaming as it dived to join its companions below.
The flock made a terrifying din.
Patkery walked to the edge of the cliff to see what the receding tide had left that was causing such a stir.
The white line of foam from the slowly rising waves was interrupted by something bright green.
It looked like a piece of cloth; something like tweed.
Strangely, the color was still so vivid, even though it had been soaked in seawater for so long—
Patkery's blue eyes suddenly widened, and his body stiffened unnaturally.
Then his square-toed boots began to run on the thick grass, thump, thump, thump, like a rapid heartbeat.
The gorge was two hundred yards away, but Patkery ran as fast as a sprinter.
He ran down the rough steps carved into the chalk cliff, panting, anger welling up in his excitement.
This was the consequence of going for a cold dip before breakfast!
Crazy, help!
And it delayed someone's breakfast.
It would be best to use the Schaefer first aid method, unless the ribs were broken; it didn't look like broken ribs, perhaps just unconsciousness.
Assure the patient loudly that everything will be fine.
Her skin color, hands and feet, were the same brown as the sand, no wonder he thought it was a piece of cloth earlier.
Crazy, help!
Who would want to swim in cold water so early in the morning if they didn't have to?
He had encountered situations where swimming was unavoidable in the past, in the port of the Red Sea, joining a landing party to assist the Arabs.
But he couldn't figure out why anyone would want to help those guys—that was when one should swim.
When you have no choice.
Orange juice with thin toast was the same.
Not nutritious enough.
Crazy, help!
Walking on this beach was not easy.
The large white round stones underfoot were treacherously slippery.
The small patches of sand that occasionally appeared were at the same level as the tide, soft and sinking.
But now he had finally reached the flock of gulls, drowned in their excited wings and sharp cries.
The Schaefer first aid method was no longer needed, and other first aid methods would be useless.
He only glanced at her and understood that the girl was beyond saving.
Although Patkery had once lifted bodies from the Red Sea tides without emotion, he now felt an inexplicable surge of emotion.
It was completely wrong for such a young life to lie here when the whole world was waking up to a bright day.
And she must have been quite pretty, her hair seemed to have been dyed, but other parts were fine.
A wave washed over her feet and receded, flowing playfully over her deep red toes.
Although he knew the tide would recede by several yards in the next minute, Patkery still dragged this lifeless mass a little further up, so as not to be further insulted by the waves.
Then he thought of making a phone call.
He looked around to see if the girl had left any clothes before entering the water.
It seemed there was nothing.
Perhaps she had left her clothes below the high tide line, so they were washed away.
Or maybe she didn't enter the water here at all.

In any case, there was nothing to cover her body with now, so Patkery turned and began to walk quickly on the beach again; he was going back to the coast guard station where the nearest telephone was.
'There's a body on the beach,' Bill Gunter was told as he picked up the receiver to call the police station.
Bill clicked his tongue between his teeth and jerked his head back.
This movement succinctly conveyed his impatience with the situation, his bewilderment at someone drowning themselves, and his smug satisfaction at having predicted the worst-case scenario.
'If these people really want to commit suicide,' his voice was devoid of emotion, 'why pick us? Aren't there plenty of beaches on the south coast?'
'Not suicide,' Patkery said during a pause in the conversation.
Bill ignored his words.

'Just because the ticket price to the south coast is a little more expensive than here! Do you think they wouldn't be so stingy if they don't care about their lives and would let themselves die with a bit of style? But no! They want to buy the cheapest tickets and come to our door one by one!'
'There are many around Beachy Head,' the fair-minded Patkery retorted breathlessly.
'Anyway, it's not suicide.'
'It must be suicide. What do you think all those cliffs are for? To defend Britain? No. They are for suicide. This is the fourth one this year. There will be more when it's time to pay income tax.'
He paused, and Patkery's words caught his attention.
'A girl. Uh, a woman. Wearing a bright green bathrobe.'
(Patkery belonged to the generation that didn't know what a swimsuit was.)
'About a hundred yards south of the gorge. No, no one there.
I have to hurry to make the call. But I'll be back there soon. Okay, we'll meet there.
Ah, hello, Captain? Yes, not a good start to the day, but we're used to it. No, just a swimming accident. Ambulance? Yes, it can almost reach the gorge.
Turn off the main road in Westover at the three-mile mark and follow the small road all the way to the woods by the gorge. Okay, see you later.'
'How can you conclude it's just a swimming accident?' Bill asked.
'She was wearing a bathrobe, didn't you hear?'
'Who says you can't commit suicide by jumping into the sea wearing a bathrobe? Intentionally making it look like an accident.'
'You can't jump into the sea at this time of year. You'll fall on the beach. And it's too obvious.'
'She might have walked into the sea and drowned slowly,' Bill said, born to argue.
'Is that so? Maybe she died of poisoning from eating too many mint candies,' Patkery said, who used to be argumentative in Arabia but later found it quite boring in daily life.
A small group of solemn-looking people surrounded the body: Patkery, Bill, the Captain, the Sergeant, and two ambulance attendants.
The younger attendant worried about being hungry and about the shame of saying such a thing, but the others were engrossed.
'Do you recognize him?' the Captain asked.
'No,' Patkery said, 'never seen her before.' Nobody had seen her.
'She shouldn't be from Westover. People there have good beaches in front of their own houses. She must be from somewhere inland.'
'Maybe she went into the water in Westover and was washed here,' the Sergeant said.
'Wrong time,' Patkery objected, 'she couldn't have been in the water that long. She must have drowned nearby.'
'Then how did she get here?' the Captain asked.
'By car, of course,' Bill said.
'Where is the car?'
'Where everyone parks: at the end of the forest track.'
'Really?' the Captain said, 'There are no cars there.'
The ambulance attendants confirmed his statement.
They had come with the police—the ambulance was waiting, and there wasn't a single other car in sight.
'This is strange,' Patkery said, 'other places are too far to walk to. At least at this time of the morning.'
'She shouldn't have walked here,' the older attendant offered his opinion.
'Rich,' he added, as if someone had asked him.
They stared at the body for a while in silence.
Yes, the attendant was right, it was a well-maintained body that had cost a lot of money.
'And where are her clothes?' the Captain worried.
Patkery explained his theory about the clothes: she had left them below the high tide line, and they were now somewhere in the sea.
'Yes, that's possible,' the Captain said: 'But how did she get here?'
'Isn't it strange for her to come swimming alone?' the younger attendant ventured boldly, suppressing his hunger.

'Nothing is strange these days,' Bill muttered: 'The amazing thing is she didn't jump off the cliff on a glider. Swimming on an empty stomach, alone, is too common. These young fools bore me to death.'
'Is that a chain on her ankle, or what?' the Sergeant asked.
It was a chain, a platinum chain.
A peculiar chain.
Each link was a c shape.
'Well then,' the Captain stood up straight, 'I suppose there's nothing more to do for now except take her to the mortuary and find out her identity.
It shouldn't be difficult.
Everything is there, nothing stolen or lost.'
'Yes,' the ambulance attendants agreed, 'her butler is probably calling the station anxiously right now.'
'Well,' the Captain said thoughtfully: 'I'm still very suspicious about how she got here, and how she—'
His gaze moved up the cliff face and stopped suddenly.
'There's someone there!' he said.
They all turned and saw a man standing on the cliff top by the gorge, looking at them with great urgency and nervousness.
As soon as they turned to face him, he disappeared in a flash.
'It's a bit too early to go for a walk now,' the Captain said, 'and why did he run away? We'd better find him for questioning.'
He and the Sergeant had only taken a couple of steps forward when they realized the man wasn't running away at all, but was finding a way into the gorge.
His thin, dark figure first appeared at the mouth of the gorge, then stumbled towards them, looking like a madman in their eyes.
As he got closer, they could hear his rapid breathing from his open mouth, although the mouth of the gorge was not far away, and he was still young.
He finally staggered to the edge of the crowd, without looking at anyone, and pushed aside the two policemen who inadvertently blocked his path to the body.
'Oh, yes, it's her! It's her!' he shouted, suddenly sat down on the ground, and tears immediately welled up.
The six of them looked at him in confusion, and a moment of silence passed.
Then the Captain patted his back kindly and said awkwardly: 'It's okay, child!'
But the young man just swayed back and forth, crying even harder.
'Alright, alright,' the Sergeant also encouraged him, speaking kindly. (On such a clear morning, it was indeed a tragic scene.)
'You know, it's no use doing this. Pull yourself together—sir.'
He noticed that the handkerchief the young man took out was of unusual quality, so he added this title at the end.
'Is she your relative?' the Captain asked, modifying his formal tone appropriately.
The young man shook his head.
'Oh, a friend?'
'She was too good to me, too good!'
'At least you can help. We're struggling to know her identity. You can tell us who she is.'
'She is my—landlady.'
'Oh, I mean, what is her name?'
'I don't know.'
'You—don't—know! Look at me, sir, pull yourself together. You are the only one who can help us. You must know the name of the lady you live with.'
'No, no, I don't know.'
'Then, what do you call her?'
'Chris.'
'Chris, what's her surname?'
'I just call her Chris.'
'And what does she call you?'
'Robin.'
'Is that your name?'
'Yes, my name is Robert Stanaway. No, Tisdall. It used to be Stanaway.'
He explained, as the Captain's gaze made him feel the need to explain.
The Captain's gaze said: 'God, give me more patience.'
But what he said was: 'I don't understand what you're saying, uh—'
'Tisdall.'
'Mr. Tisdall. Can you please tell me how this young lady got here this morning?'
'Oh, of course, she came by car.'
'By car, oh? Where is the car now?'
'I stole it.'
'What?'
'I stole it. But I drove it back. It was too despicable. I felt so low, so I came back.
I couldn't find her on the road, so I thought she might be wandering around here.
Then I saw you all gathered around something—oh, God, God!' He began to sway again.
'Where do you live with this young lady?' the Captain asked, his formal tone slowly returning: 'In Westover?'
'Oh, no. She has—no, I mean, she used to have—oh, God—a farm called Blair, just outside Medley.'
'Inland, a mile and a half from here,' Patkery added, as the Captain, not being a local, looked confused.
'Do you live there yourselves, or do you have servants?'
'Only a woman from the village—Mrs. Pits—who does the cooking.'
'I understand.'
A brief silence.
'Alright, brother,' the Captain nodded to the ambulance attendants, who immediately bent down to handle the stretcher.
The young man took a deep breath and covered his face with his hands again.
'To the mortuary, Captain?'
'Yes.'
The young man's hands suddenly moved from his face.
'Oh, no! No! She has a home. Shouldn't she be sent home?'
'We can't send an unidentified female corpse to an uninhabited farmhouse.'
'It's not a farmhouse,' the young man corrected himself, 'no, I don't think so. But—the mortuary? It sounds terrifying. Oh, God!' He began to cry loudly: 'Why did this happen?'
'Davis,' the Captain said to the Sergeant, 'you and the others go back and report. I'm going to—where is that? Blair? —with Mr. Tisdall.'
The two ambulance attendants carried the heavy stretcher away, crunching on the stones, followed by Patkery and Bill.
As their footsteps receded, the Captain spoke again.
'I don't think you came to swim with your landlady, did you?'
A spasm of embarrassment crossed Tisdall's face.
He hesitated.
'No. I—I usually don't swim before breakfast. I—I'm not good at anything like that.'
The Captain nodded noncommittally.
'What time did she leave?'
'I don't know. She told me last night that if she woke up early, she would go for a swim in the gorge. I woke up early, but she was already gone.'
'I see. I say, Mr. Tisdall, if you've recovered, I think we should be on our way.'
'Yes, yes, of course. I'm fine.'

He stood up, tidied himself, and then the two of them crossed the beach quietly, climbed the gorge steps, and returned to where Tisdall said he had parked the car: under the shade of the trees at the end of the track.
It was a beautiful car, even a bit too luxurious.
Milky white body, two seats, and a space for luggage between the seats and the trunk, where an extra person could sit if necessary.
The Captain searched the area and found a woman's coat and a pair of sheepskin boots that women liked to wear at winter horse races.
'This is what she was wearing when she went down to the beach. Just a coat over her swimsuit, and boots on her feet. There's also a towel here.'
There was indeed a towel. The Captain found it: a brightly colored green and orange towel.
'Strange, why didn't she bring a towel to the beach?' he said.
'She liked to let the sun dry her.'
'You seem to know the habits of this lady you don't know the name of very well.'
The Captain sat in the passenger seat.
'How long have you lived with her?'
'Lived in her house,' Tisdall corrected, showing a sharp tone for the first time: 'Please clarify, Captain, this will save you a lot of trouble: Chris is my landlady, nothing more.
There are only two of us living on her farm, but even without a large staff, our relationship is proper.
Is this strange to you?'
'Very strange,' the Captain admitted frankly. 'And what is this for?'
He was looking through a paper bag containing two nearly rotten rolls.
'Oh, I brought them for her to eat. I could only find these.
I've been used to eating a roll after swimming since I was a child.
I thought she might be happy to have something to eat.'
The car slid down the steep track and entered the main road of Westover.
They crossed the road and drove into the opposite lane.
The sign read: 'Medley 1, Lyddstone 3'.
'So you didn't plan to steal the car when you followed her to the beach?'
'Of course not!' Tisdall said, feigning indignation as much as possible: 'I never even thought about it until I saw the car parked there on the mountain. Even now, I can't believe I actually did it.
I was confused then, but I've never done anything like this before.'
'Was she in the sea then?'
'I don't know, I didn't look. If I had seen her, even from a distance, I wouldn't have done it.
I threw the bread in, drove the car, and ran.
When I came to my senses, I was halfway to Canterbury. I didn't stop for a second, turned back immediately, and drove the car straight back.'
The Captain said nothing to this.
'You still haven't told me how long you've been living on that farm?'
'Since midnight on Saturday.'
It was Thursday today.
'And you still expect me to believe that you don't know your landlady's surname?'
'No. It's a bit strange, I know. I thought so myself at first.
I used to be very traditional, but she seemed to think it was natural.
After spending a day together, we accepted each other.
I felt like I had known her for years.'
Seeing that the Captain said nothing, but was full of suspicion like heat radiating from a stove, he added a sentence to imply his displeasure: 'If I knew her surname, why wouldn't I tell you?'
'How should I know?' the Captain said impolitely, glancing sideways at the young man's pale but composed face.
He seemed to have recovered quite quickly from his excitement and grief.
Really shallow, these new humans.
No deep emotions for anything.
Just hysterical.
The love they speak of is just a casual affair by the barn, everything else is 'affectation' to them.
No principles.
Can't withstand hardship.
When things get difficult, they run away.
Didn't get enough slaps as a child.
New ideas are giving children whatever they want.
Look at the result.
Crying by the sea one minute, and calm as if nothing happened the next.
Then the Captain noticed the overly delicate hands on the steering wheel, trembling slightly.
Regardless of how Robert Tisdall felt, he was certainly not calm.
'Is this it?' the Captain asked as the car slowed down near a fenced garden.
'This is it.'
It was a half-timbered farmhouse, about five bays wide; a seven-foot-high hedge of brambles and honeysuckle separated it from the street, with roses hanging down.
A heavenly beautiful house for those Americans, holidaymakers, and photographers.
Several small windows were quietly open, and the charming blue front door was also open, with the gleam of a brass pot on the wall faintly visible in the shadows.

As they walked up the red brick path, a small woman appeared on the doorstep, conspicuously wearing a white apron, with sparse hair tied in a bun at the back, and a black silk nest-shaped object precariously perched on top of her head.
As soon as Tisdall saw her, his steps slowed down, allowing her to clearly see the trouble she was about to face from the imposing figure of the Captain in uniform.
However, Mrs. Pits was the widow of a police officer, so her tense face showed no sign of unease.
In the past, the appearance of a uniformed figure on the doorstep meant that she should prepare a meal, so her thoughts were directed towards that.
'I've made some pancakes. They'll be hot soon. Better turn off the stove. Please tell Miss Robinson when she comes in, sir?'
Then she recognized the uniformed man as a policeman: 'Don't tell me you're driving without a license, sir!'
'Her name is Miss Robinson? She had an accident.' the Captain said.
'A car accident? Good heavens! She always drives recklessly. Is it serious?'
'Not a car accident. The accident happened in the water.'
'Oh,' she said slowly, 'then it's serious!'
'What do you mean by 'then it's serious'?'
'There's only one outcome for an accident in the water.'
'Yes.' the Captain agreed.

'Alas, really,' she said, musing sadly. Then her attitude changed abruptly: 'Where have you been?' she cursed, glaring at the dejected Tisdall as if she were glaring at a fish on a fishmonger's slab in the Westover market.
Her superficial deference to the 'gentleman class' vanished with the appearance of disaster.
She had privately considered Tisdall a 'coward', and now he looked exactly like that.
The Captain found it amusing but didn't show it.
'This gentleman was not present.'
'He must have been. He followed her closely.'
'How do you know?'
'I saw it. I live in the farmhouse not far ahead.'
'Do you know any other residences of Miss Robinson? I believe this is not her permanent residence.'
'No, of course not. She has only lived in this house for a month. The owner is Owen Hughes.'
She paused, skilfully letting the significance of this name sink in.

'But he is currently filming a movie in Hollywood. It's supposed to be about a Spanish count. He said he had already filmed an Italian count and a French count, and he believed that filming a Spanish count would be a brand new experience.
A very nice person, this Mr. Hughes.
Despite so much flattery, he hasn't been spoiled.
You probably won't believe it, but a girl came to me, gave me five pounds, and asked for the sheets he slept in.
I gave her my own sheets.
She wasn't even ashamed.
She wanted to give me twenty-five shillings for his pillowcases.
I really don't know what the world is coming to, I really don't—'
'Does Miss Robinson have any other residences?'
'Besides this, I don't know of any others.'
'Did she notify you in advance by letter before coming?'
'Letters! No! She sent telegrams.
I thought she would write letters, but I swear she never did.
She probably sent six telegrams a day from the Lyddstone post office.
Most of them were delivered by my husband Albert when he was off school.
Some of them were as long as three or four sheets of telegram paper.'
'Then, do you know if she has any acquaintances around here?'
'No. Except Mr. Stanaway.'
'Not a single one!'

'Not a single one. Once—I was telling her the trick of flushing the toilet, to press it hard and then release it lightly—once she said: 'Mrs. Pits,' she said: 'Have you ever felt that you hated someone just by looking at their face?'
I said I was a bit repulsed by some people.
She said: 'Not some people, Mrs. Pits. All people.
Purely disgusted by people.'
I said when I felt like that, I took a spoonful of castor oil.
She laughed and said it was a good idea.
If everyone had such a good idea, peace would be restored in two days.'
Mussolini never thought of that.
'She said.'
'Is she from London?'
'Yes. She only went back once or twice in the three weeks she was here.
Last weekend she brought Mr. Stanaway back.
She glanced at Tisdall disdainfully again, as if he were something worse than dirt.
'Doesn't he know her address?' she asked.
'Nobody knows,' the Captain said, 'I'll see if I can find anything in her documents.'
Mrs. Pits led the way, and they entered the living room, cool, dim, and smelling of sweet peas.
'How are you handling her—I mean, her body?' she asked.
'In the mortuary.'
This sentence seemed to bring the tragedy into the house for the first time.
'Oh, my God.'
She moved the hem of her apron slowly on the smooth dining table. 'I'm still making pancakes.'
This was not a lament for wasted pancakes, but her tribute to the impermanence of worldly affairs.
'I hope you need breakfast,' she said to Tisdall, her tone softening, as if she subconsciously understood that humans were at best puppets of fate.
Tisdall didn't want breakfast.
He shook his head and turned to the window, while the Captain busied himself searching for something on the desk.
'I wouldn't mind a pancake,' the Captain said, looking through the documents on the table.
'You can't find better in Kent, at least I think so myself.
Perhaps Mr. Stanaway would like a cup of tea.'
She went into the kitchen.
'So you don't know her surname is Robinson?' the Captain said, looking up.
'Mrs. Pits always called her 'Miss'. Besides, does she look like she's named Robinson?'
The Captain himself had not really believed she was named Robinson, so he dropped the subject.
Tisdall immediately said again: 'If you don't need me, I'd like to walk in the garden. It's—it's too stuffy here.'
'Alright. Don't forget I still need the car to go back to Westover.'
'I told you, it was an impulse. And now I can't steal a car and run away.'
Not stupid, the Captain thought. Not bad-tempered either.
In any case, this person is not a simpleton.
Scattered on the desk were several magazines, newspapers, half a pack of hard-box cigarettes, a few jigsaw puzzles, a nail file, nail polish, several silk cloths, and a pile of miscellaneous items.
In fact, there was everything, except a notepad.
The only documents were bills from local businesses, mostly paid receipts.
Even if this woman was messy and disorganized, she at least had a cautious personality.
Those receipts might be wrinkled and torn, and difficult to find, but at least they weren't thrown away.
The morning's tranquility, Mrs. Pits's energetic tea-making in the kitchen, and the anticipation of hot pancakes made the Captain feel quite comfortable.
He began to indulge in one of his habits while searching the desk.
He whistled.
The Captain's whistling was slow, round, and sweet, but whistling was still whistling.
He whistled 'Sing to Me Occasionally' with a tremor, not forgetting to add embellishments, such performance satisfied his subconscious.
His wife once showed him a copy of 'The Post' that said whistling was a sign of an empty mind.
This did not cure him.
Suddenly, this moment of melody was interrupted.
Without warning, there was a mocking rap on the half-open door of the living room—tap—tick—tap-tap-tick-tock!
A man's voice said: 'So you're hiding here!'
The door opened wide, and a short, dark stranger stood in the doorway.
'Hey—yo—yo,' he said, drawing it out into several syllables.
He stood there staring at the Captain, grinning happily.
'I thought you were Chris! What wind blew the policeman here? Was there a theft?'
'No, no thieves.'
The Captain tried to collect his thoughts.
'Don't tell me Chris is throwing another wild party! I thought she stopped doing that years ago. That doesn't fit with good taste.'
'No, in fact—'
'Where is she?' he shouted loudly, with full force, towards the upstairs: 'Yo—ho! Chris. Come down, you guy, still hiding!'
Turning to the Captain: 'She's been hiding for almost three weeks. Probably dazzled by the studio lights, I guess.
They all get neurotic sooner or later.
But the last one was so successful, of course everyone treats her as a cash cow.'
He hummed a passage from 'Sing to Me Occasionally' with mock seriousness.
'So I thought you were Chris, you're whistling her song. And you're whistling pretty well.'
'Her—song?'
Immediately, the Captain hoped this would give him a clue.
'Yes, her song. Whose else would it be?
You don't think it's mine, do you, old man? Absolutely not.
I wrote the song, of course.
But it's nothing special.
It's still her song.
Maybe she's not perfect yet! Huh? Isn't this a good song?'
'I can't say.'
If this person were not so garrulous, he might have been able to figure out some things.
'Haven't you seen 'The Iron Bars' yet?'
'No, I don't think so.'
'That's the worst thing about radio and records: the vitality of the film is drained away.
Perhaps by the time you hear Chris singing that song in the movie, you'll be so sick of it you'll want to throw up.
That's not fair to the movie.
It's good for composers, but cruel to movies, terribly cruel.
There should be some kind of agreement.
Hey, Chris! I've been looking for her everywhere, and she's not here?'
He looked dejected, like a disappointed child.
'If she walked in and saw me, it wouldn't be half as interesting as me walking in and finding her.
Do you think—'
'Excuse me, sir—uh—I don't know your name yet.'
'My name is Jay Hammer. Jason on my birth certificate. I wrote 'If I Can't Have June'. You've probably whistled this song too—'
'Mr. Hammer. Is the lady who lived—or used to live—here, a movie star?'
'Is she a movie star?'
Slowly rising surprise stopped Mr. Hammer's words for a moment. Then he thought he must have misunderstood something.
'Wait, Chris lived here, right?'
'The lady who lives here is called Chris, yes.
But—well, maybe you can help us.
An accident happened—unfortunately—and apparently she said her surname was Robinson.'
The man laughed heartily.
'Robinson! That's a good joke.
I always thought she lacked imagination and couldn't come up with spontaneous lines. Do you believe she's named Robinson?'
'Uh, no, not really.'

'Didn't I just say that! Who told her to treat me like a discarded film scrap on the editing room floor, so that I would in turn lift her bottom? She might lock me in the freezer all day, but it would be worth it.
Anyway, I'm not a gentleman, so I might as well tell you.
Captain, the lady's name is Christine Clay.
'Christine Clay!' the Captain said.
His jaw dropped, completely out of control.
'Christine Clay!' Mrs. Pits murmured, standing at the doorway, having forgotten the plate of pancakes in her hand.
'Christine Clay!' the afternoon newspaper's promotional posters shouted.
'Christine Clay!' the headlines screamed.
'Christine Clay!' they discussed on the radio.
'Christine Clay!' the neighbors whispered.
Everyone in the world stopped to say this name.
Christine Clay drowned!
Only one person in civilized society said: 'Who is Christine Clay?'
This was said by a clever young man at a Bloomsbury party, and he only said it to be clever.
Because a woman lost her life, many things began to happen in the world.
A man in California called a woman in Greenwich Village.
A Texas pilot worked overtime at night, carrying Clay's film copies to catch a screening.
A New York company canceled an order.
An Italian nobleman went bankrupt: because he had expected to sell his yacht to her.
A man in Philadelphia ate his first good meal in months because he revealed a story of 'back when I knew her'.
A woman began to perform at the Touquet nightclub because now her chance had come.
A man in a British parish knelt down to thank God.
The press, which had been silent for a while, also quickly moved in this unexpected whirlwind.
The 'Horn' recalled Bart from the Brighton beauty pageant.

Bartholomew, their 'writer' (Bart was inexplicably grateful—he talked about butchers eating meat as soon as he returned), and Jimmy Hopkins, a star reporter who covered 'crime and passion', were interviewing a boring, vulgar murder case in Brevard.
(The 'Horn' had degenerated to this extent.)

Photojournalists abandoned their race cars, interviews, celebrity weddings, cricket matches, and people who were going to Mars in hot air balloons, and swarmed into the Kent farmhouse, the South Street inn, and the well-equipped Hampshire manor like locusts.
Christine Clay's rental of a charming retreat in the countryside, hiding in an unknown and remote farm without her friends and family knowing, added a colorful chapter to her death.

The caption under the photo of the manor (the garden was in the foreground because the yew trees blocked the house) was: 'Christine Clay's House' (in fact, she only rented it for a summer, but a rented house wasn't sensational enough); next to these impressive photos were photos of houses hidden in rose bushes, with the caption: 'Places she loved during her life.'
Her publicist shed tears over this, as if major news had occurred after the newspaper deadline.

Anyone who understood human nature, upon observing the effects of Christine Clay's death, would find that although her death caused regret, panic, shock, remorse, and various other emotional reactions, it seemed that no one felt sorrow.
The only thing that could be called genuine emotion was Robert Tisdall's hysterical episode while lying on her corpse.
But who can say how much of it was self-pity?
Compared to Christine's status as an international superstar, such a scene was merely a small supporting role.
As for her acquaintances, panic was their main reaction to this unfortunate news.
But there were exceptions.

Kuhn, who was scheduled to direct her third and final film in Britain, might have been disappointed, but Le Yong (real name Tomkins), the actor who was supposed to play opposite her, was greatly relieved; with Clay in the film, it might have been glamorous on the surface, but it would have been a heavy burden on his box office.
The Duchess of Trent had arranged a luncheon party with Clay as the attraction, intending to regain her status as the queen of London society, but she could only grit her teeth now.
But Lydia Gidge was overjoyed because she had predicted Clay's death.
Although she was a successful social observer, it was extraordinary to guess so accurately.
'My dear, you are amazing!' her friends complimented her. 'My dear, you are amazing!' endlessly.

Lydia was so overcome with joy that she attended party after party from morning till night, just to savor that wonderful feeling again when entering, and to hear others say: 'Lydia is here! My dear, you are so...'
Immersed in the admiration of others.
No, as everyone saw, not a single heart was broken because Christine Clay was no longer in the world.
Everyone took out their mourning clothes to dust them off, hoping to be invited to the funeral.
But first, an autopsy.
It was during the autopsy that the first faint tremors of the coming storm began to appear.
The first to notice the ripples on the calm water was Jimmy Hopkins.
He got the nickname 'Jammy' because whenever there was a good news story, he would exclaim happily: 'Jam! Jam!'
And his philosophy was 'Anything that goes on the rotary press is good.'

Hopkins had a keen sense for good news, and it was precisely because of this that he stopped halfway while analyzing the various characters who had crowded into the small municipal hall of Kent to chase news for Bart, and stared with wide eyes.
Because through the loose caps of two paparazzi, he saw a calm male face that was more newsworthy than anything in the house.
'See something?' Bart asked.
'See what!' Hopkins slid off the bench, just as the coroner sat down and asked for quiet.
'Save me a seat,' he whispered, and then slipped out of the room.
He came in again from the back door, skillfully squeezed to his destination, and sat down.
The man turned his head to look at the uninvited guest.
'Good morning, Inspector.'
Hopkins said.
The Inspector looked at him with disgust.
'If it weren't for making a living, I wouldn't do this,' Hopkins said, putting on a hypocritical voice.
The coroner again asked for quiet, but the Inspector's expression had softened.
Soon, during the commotion when Patkery came in to provide evidence, Hopkins said: 'Why would Scotland Yard be here, Inspector?
'Just observing.'
'I see. So you're just an observer unit.
Crime is light lately, isn't it?'
Seeing that the Inspector didn't react: 'Oh, do a good deed, Inspector.
What's the situation? Is there any mystery in the cause of death? Any doubts, huh?
If you don't want to make your words public, I am the most reliable safe.'
'You are the most reliable gadfly.'
'Oh, do you know how thick the skin I have to pierce to draw blood?'
This only earned a smile and nothing else.
'Listen to me.
Just reveal one thing. Will today's autopsy be postponed?'
'I wouldn't be surprised if it were.'
'Thank you.
That's enough.
Hopkins said, half mockingly, half seriously, and left the room again.
He called Albert—Mrs. Pits's son—who was hanging on the wall like a limpet, and persuaded him that two shillings was better than a boring autopsy that only offered a corner view.
Then he sent him to deliver a telegram to Lyddstone that would keep 'The Horn' busy.
After that, he went back to Bart.
'Something is fishy,' he replied in a low voice to Bart's questioning eyebrows.
'Scotland Yard is here, that's Grant, the one behind the red hat.
Today's autopsy will be postponed.
The murderer has been found!'
'Not here!' Bart said, worried about the crowd.
'Yes.'
Jimmy agreed. 'Who is the one in the flannel trousers?'
'The boyfriend.'
'I thought the boyfriend was Jay Hammer.'
'He was. This is a new one.'
'Crime of passion?'
'I'd bet on it.'
'Shift of affection, I think?'
'Yes.
That's what they say.
It seems she played them.
There should be a good reason for murder, I think.'
All the most basic evidence—discovery of the body, confirmation, etc.
As soon as the coroner obtained this information, the procedure was immediately concluded, and another autopsy was scheduled.

Hopkins judged that Clay's death was clearly not an accident, and Scotland Yard would not make any arrests for now, so to get information, he would undoubtedly have to find the young man in the flannel trousers.
His name was Tisdall.

Bart said that all the newspaper reporters in Britain wanted to interview him yesterday (at that time Hopkins was rushing back from the fire poker murder case), but he was unexpectedly difficult to deal with.
He called reporters carrion crows, vultures, rats, and other unmentionable words, as if he were unaware of the power of the media.
No one dared to be so rude to the media and get away with it.
But Hopkins was very confident in his ability to lure people.
'You're Tisdall, aren't you?' he asked casually, as he 'happened' to walk alongside the young man in the crowd heading for the door.
The young man's face fell, and he immediately became hostile.
'Yes, I am.'
A wary voice.
'You're not the nephew of Old Tom Tisdall, are you?'
The hostility on his face disappeared instantly.
'Yes. Do you know Uncle Tom?'
'Not well,' Hopkins admitted, surprised that there was indeed a Tom Tisdall.
'You seem to know that I no longer use Stanaway?'
'Yes. Heard it,' Hopkins replied, not knowing if Stanaway was a horse or something.
'Are you employed now?'
By the time they reached the door, Hopkins had already gotten to know him well.
'Need a ride? Let's have dinner together!'
Too beautiful! The headline was ready in less than half an hour.
They said this kid was difficult to deal with? No doubt about it: he, James Brook Hopkins, was the most outstanding journalist.
'Sorry, Mr. Hopkins,' Grant's cheerful voice appeared behind him, 'I hate to spoil your fun, but Mr. Tisdall and I have an appointment.'
Then, seeing Tisdall's surprised expression, and Hopkins about to realize what was going on, he added: 'We hope he can help us.'
'I don't understand,' Tisdall finally revealed himself.
Hopkins realized that Tisdall had no idea who Grant was, and quickly said gleefully: 'This is Inspector Grant of Scotland Yard,' he said, 'he hasn't failed to solve any case he's handled.'
'I hope you will write my obituary,' Grant said.
'I hope I have that honor,' the reporter said eagerly.
Then they noticed Tisdall.
His face was like parchment, dry and old, and expressionless.
Only the throbbing of the veins on his temples indicated that he was alive.
The reporter and the inspector stood there, surprised at the unexpected effect Hopkins' announcement had.
Then, they saw the young man's knees begin to buckle, and Grant quickly supported his arm.
'Quick! Come and sit down. My car is right here.'
He supported the clearly unconscious Tisdall, pushed him into the back seat of a black touring car, and walked through the idle, chattering crowd.
'Westover,' he said to the driver, and then got in and sat next to Tisdall.
As they drove towards the road at a snail's pace, Grant saw Hopkins still standing there.
When Jimmy Hopkins stood still for more than three minutes, it meant he was racking his brains.
From now on—the inspector sighed—the gadfly would become a bloodhound.
And now the inspector's mind could not rest either.

The previous night, the worried county police chief had notified him overnight that they didn't want to make a fuss foolishly, but there was a very small but inexplicable problem that they couldn't find a satisfactory explanation for.

Everyone in the police station had thought about the problem, from the chief down to the officer who had investigated the beach, they attacked each other's arguments, and in the end, the only consensus was: they all wanted to push the responsibility onto someone else.
Of course, it's good to diligently investigate the crimes in your hands and get the credit for solving them, but that's only if there's really a crime.

If you just assume a crime has been committed based on the body, and fail, it's not that you're afraid of losing face, but that you're afraid of being pointed at and mocked by others, which is something they fundamentally don't want to get involved in.
Therefore, Grant canceled his theater reservation and went south to Westover.

He met the local police team, which was not very sophisticated, patiently listened to their conflicting opinions and the forensic doctor's views, and by bedtime at dawn, he was eagerly looking forward to interviewing Robert Tisdall.
Now Tisdall was by his side, still in a semi-coma state, too scared to speak, due to the unexpected sight of someone from Scotland Yard.
Yes, there was indeed a crime, no doubt about it.
The driver, Cork, was in the car, and it wasn't time to ask questions. Before they returned to Westover, Tisdall should have sobered up.
Grant took a small bottle of wine from the car's storage compartment and offered it to Tisdall.
Tisdall took it with a tremor and drank a large gulp without hesitation.
Soon after, he began to apologize for his weakness.
'I don't know what's wrong with me. The whole thing has been a terrible blow to me.
I haven't slept, and a lot of things keep popping into my head.
Or rather, I keep thinking about things in my head, and I can't stop.
Then, at the autopsy, it seemed—is there something wrong with it? I mean, isn't this a simple drowning? Why was the autopsy postponed?'
'One or two things have bothered the police a bit.'
'What things, for example?'
'I think we'll discuss everything when we get to Westover.'
'Will everything I say become evidence against myself?'
He smiled strangely, but without malice.
'You've said what's on my mind,' the Inspector said calmly, and they fell silent.
By the time they reached the county police chief's office, Tisdall, although a bit tired, looked quite normal.
In fact, he was so normal that when Grant introduced him, saying 'This is Mr. Tisdall,' the friendly chief was about to shake his hand, but he quickly stopped himself and straightened his expression.
'Hello. Well, cough!' He cleared his throat to return to his normal state.
I can't do that, I know.
God, absolutely not.
This is a murder suspect.
He doesn't look like it, not at all.
But anything is possible these days.
The most charming guys are—
Some things that I only recently learned actually existed long ago.
It's a pity.
But of course...

hierarchy.structure: The document is structured as a narrative that unfolds chronologically, beginning with a discovery and progressing through investigation and interviews. It moves from a solitary walk to a police inquiry, introducing multiple characters and plot threads.
